column2: On Thursday afternoon Mary was surprised, in the midst of some little bustle in which she was engaged, by the entrance of Will Wilson. He looked strange, at least it was strange to see any different expression on his face to his usual joyous beaming appearance.

column2: So much the better, and perhaps she could cover her father's rudeness by her own civility to so kind a friend.

column2: So half listening to her father's movements up-stairs, (passionate, violent, restless motions they were) and half attending to Job Legh, she tried to pay him all due regard.
column3: So half listening to her father's movements up stairs, (passionate, violent, restless motions they were) and half attending to Job Legh, she tried to pay him all due regard.

column2: When does thy father start, Mary?

column2: That plaguing question again.

column2: I'm just getting him a bit of supper.

column2: Is Margaret very well?"

column2: Yes, she's well enough.	Yes, she's well enough.

column2: She's meaning to go and keep Alice Wilson company for an hour or so this evening; as soon as she thinks her nephew will have started for Liverpool; for she fancies the old woman will feel a bit lonesome.

column2: Th' Union is paying for your father, I suppose?"

column2: You're one of th' Union, Job?"
column3: You're one of t h' Union, Job?"

column2: Ay! I'm one, sure enough; but I'm but a sleeping partner in the concern.	Ay! I'm one, sure enough; but I'm but a sleeping partner in the concern.

column2: I were obliged to become a member for peace, else I don't go along with 'em.
column3: I were obliged to become a member for peace, else I don't go along with 'em.

column2: Yo see they think themselves wise, and me silly, for differing with them; well!
column3: Yo see they think themselves wise, and me silly, for differing with them; well!

column2: there's no harm in that.
column3: there's no harm in that.

column2: But then they won't let me be silly in peace and quietness, but will force me to be as wise as they are; now that's not British liberty, I say.
column3: But then they won't let me be silly in peace and quietness, but will force me to be as wise as they are; now that's not British liberty, I say.

column2: I'm forced to be wise according to their notions, else they parsecute me, and sarve me out."
column3: I'm forced to be wise according to their notions, else they parsecute me, and sarve me out."

column2: What could her father be doing up-stairs?

column2: Tramping and banging about. Why did he not come down?

column2: Or why did not Job go?

column2: The supper would be spoilt.

column2: But Job had no notion of going.

column2: You see my folly is this, Mary.	You see my folly is this, Mary.

column2: I would take what I could get; I think half a loaf is better than no bread.
column3: I would take what I could get; I think half a loaf is better than no bread.

column2: I would work for low wages rather than sit idle and starve.
column3: I would work for low wages rather than sit idle and starve.

column2: But, comes the Trades' Union, and says, 'Well, if you take the half-loaf, we'll worry you out of your life.
column3: But, comes the Trades' Union, and says, 'Well, if you take the half loaf, we'll worry you out of your life.

column2: Will you be clemmed, or will you be worried?' Now clemming is a quiet death, and worrying isn't, so I choose clemming, and come into th' Union.
column3: Will you be clemmed, or will you be worried?' Now clemming is a quiet death, and worrying isn't, so I choose clemming, and come into t h' Union.

column2: But I wish they'd leave me free, if I am a fool."
column3: But I wish they'd leave me free, if I am a fool."

column2: Creak, creak, went the stairs.
column3: Creak, creak, went the stairs.

column2: Her father was coming down at last.
column3: Her father was coming down at last.

column2: Yes, he came down, but more doggedly fierce than before, and made up for his journey, too; with his little bundle on his arm.
column3: Yes, he came down, but more doggedly fierce than before, and made up for his journey, too; with his little bundle on his arm.

column2: He went up to Job, and, more civilly than Mary expected, wished him good-bye.
column3: He went up to Job, and, more civilly than Mary expected, wished him good bye.

column2: He then turned to her, and in a short cold manner, bade her farewell.
column3: He then turned to her, and in a short cold manner, bade her farewell.

column2: Oh! father, don't go yet.	Oh! father, don't go yet.

column2: Your supper is all ready.
column3: Your supper is all ready.

column2: Stay one moment!"
column3: Stay one moment!"

column2: But he pushed her away, and was gone.
column3: But he pushed her away, and was gone.

column2: She followed him to the door, her eyes blinded by sudden tears; she stood there looking after him. He was so strange, so cold, so hard.
column3: She followed him to the door, her eyes blinded by sudden tears; she stood there looking after him. He was so strange, so cold, so hard.

column2: Suddenly, at the end of the court, he turned, and saw her standing there; he came back quickly, and took her in his arms.
column3: Suddenly, at the end of the court, he turned, and saw her standing there; he came back quickly, and took her in his arms.

column2: God bless thee, Mary!--God in heaven bless thee, poor child! She threw her arms round his neck.
column3: God bless thee, Mary!--God in heaven bless thee, poor child! She threw her arms round his neck.

column2: Don't go yet, father; I can't bear you to go yet.	Don't go yet, father; I can't bear you to go yet.

column2: Come in, and eat some supper; you look so ghastly; dear father, do!"
column3: Come in, and eat some supper; you look so ghastly; dear father, do!"

column2: No, he said, faintly and mournfully.
column3: No, he said, faintly and mournfully.

column2: It's best as it is.	It's best as it is.

column2: I couldn't eat, and it's best to be off.
column3: I couldn't eat, and it's best to be off.

column2: I cannot be still at home. I must be moving."
column3: I cannot be still at home. I must be moving."

column2: So saying, he unlaced her soft twining arms, and kissing her once more, set off on his fierce errand.
column3: So saying, he unlaced her soft twining arms, and kissing her once more, set off on his fierce errand.

column2: And he was out of sight!
column3: And he was out of sight!

column2: She did not know why, but she had never before felt so depressed, so desolate.
column3: She did not know why, but she had never before felt so depressed, so desolate.

column2: She turned in to Job, who sat there still.
column3: She turned in to Job, who sat there still.

column2: Her father, as soon as he was out of sight, slackened his pace, and fell into that heavy listless step, which told as well as words could do, of hopelessness and weakness.
column3: Her father, as soon as he was out of sight, slackened his pace, and fell into that heavy listless step, which told as well as words could do, of hopelessness and weakness.

column2: It was getting dark, but he loitered on, returning no greeting to any one.
column3: It was getting dark, but he loitered on, returning no greeting to any one.

column2: A child's cry caught his ear.
column3: A child's cry caught his ear.

column2: His thoughts were running on little Tom; on the dead and buried child of happier years.
column3: His thoughts were running on little Tom; on the dead and buried child of happier years.

column2: He followed the sound of the wail, that might have been _his_, and found a poor little mortal, who had lost his way, and whose grief had choked up his thoughts to the single want, "Mammy, mammy." With tender address, John Barton soothed the little laddie, and with beautiful patience he gathered fragments of meaning from the half spoken words which came mingled with sobs from the terrified little heart.
column3: He followed the sound of the wail, that might have been underscore his underscore, and found a poor little mortal, who had lost his way, and whose grief had choked up his thoughts to the single want, "Mammy, mammy." With tender address, john Barton soothed the little laddie, and with beautiful patience he gathered fragments of meaning from the half spoken words which came mingled with sobs from the terrified little heart.

column2: So, aided by inquiries here and there from a passer-by, he led and carried the little fellow home, where his mother had been too busy to miss him, but now received him with thankfulness, and with an eloquent Irish blessing.
column3: So, aided by inquiries here and there from a passer by, he led and carried the little fellow home, where his mother had been too busy to miss him, but now received him with thankfulness, and with an eloquent Irish blessing.

column2: When John heard the words of blessing, he shook his head mournfully, and turned away to retrace his steps.
column3: When john heard the words of blessing, he shook his head mournfully, and turned away to retrace his steps.

column2: Let us leave him.
column3: Let us leave him.

column2: Mary took her sewing after he had gone, and sat on, and sat on, trying to listen to Job, who was more inclined to talk than usual. She had conquered her feeling of impatience towards him so far as to be able to offer him her father's rejected supper; and she even tried to eat herself.
column3: Mary took her sewing after he had gone, and sat on, and sat on, trying to listen to Job, who was more inclined to talk than usual. She had conquered her feeling of impatience towards him so far as to be able to offer him her father's rejected supper; and she even tried to eat herself.

column2: But her heart failed her.
column3: But her heart failed her.

column2: A leaden weight seemed to hang over her; a sort of presentiment of evil, or perhaps only an excess of low-spirited feeling in consequence of the two departures which had taken place that afternoon.
column3: A leaden weight seemed to hang over her; a sort of presentiment of evil, or perhaps only an excess of low spirited feeling in consequence of the two departures which had taken place that afternoon.

column2: She wondered how long Job Legh would sit.
column3: She wondered how long Job Legh would sit.

column2: She did not like putting down her work, and crying before him, and yet she had never in her life longed so much to be alone in order to indulge in a good hearty burst of tears.
column3: She did not like putting down her work, and crying before him, and yet she had never in her life longed so much to be alone in order to indulge in a good hearty burst of tears.

column2: Well, Mary, she suddenly caught him saying, "I thought you'd be a bit lonely to-night; and as Margaret were going to cheer th' old woman, I said I'd go and keep th' young un company; and a very pleasant, chatty evening we've had; very.

column3: Only I wonder as Margaret is not come back."

column2: And it's real beautiful to see her cross the road.

column2: With a few more sorrowful remarks they separated for the night, and Mary was left alone in her house, to meditate on the heavy day that had passed over her head.

column2: Everything seemed going wrong.

column2: Will gone; her father gone--and so strangely too!
column3: Will gone; her father gone-and so strangely too!

column2: And to a place so mysteriously distant as Glasgow seemed to be to her!
column3: And to a place so mysteriously distant as Glasgow seemed to be to her!
